robrambusch wrote:

>--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Paul Hodgetts <phodgetts@a...> wrote:
>[snip...] 
>  
>
>>Once you have unit tests for your rules, changing a rule's
>>behavior should have some effect on the tests.  The assertions
>>that break tell you what the behavioral change was.  If nothing
>>breaks, perhaps that says the test coverage is not sufficient,
>>or the rule change had no practical effect.Paul:
>>    
>>
>
>Thank you for your comprehensive answer. Let's presume I've reached
>the stage where I have successfully implemented the rules engine along
>with a full suite of unit tests. Would I be violating any canons by
>having JUnit output its results in some text-like form to enable quick
>comparisons between result sets of different rules changes ? Is there
>a more elegant way to accomplish this ? I'm essentially trying to come
>up with a quick way to tell the user "When you change Rule # 5 that
>way, loans 1, 4 and 7 fail but 2,3 and 89 now pass.".
>  
>
JUnit (like other xUnits) is meant to test whether your code behaves 
correctly with respect to the requirements. It seems like you want to 
use JUnit to 'experiment' with your rules. If you have a set of loans 
that should be accepted and a set of loans that should not be accepted, 
you could write tests for these (perhaps parameterized tests to make 
things easier, so you only need to write two tests) and experiment as 
you like. You can also write a custom TestListener that reports test 
success and failure in a result file, that also reads the file(s) with 
the rules and writes them to the same result file, so you later have an 
overview which rule set performed how (make sure you write to a new file 
each time, so you can compare, or append at the of the file). In this 
case you would also need a custom TestRunner, to write the rules to the 
result file when the testsuite starts.
